children.definition: Predict tertiary structure of protein sequence(s) without homologs of known structure.
Model protein backbone conformation.
comment: Methods might require a preliminary C(alpha) trace.
Scaffold selection, scaffold search, epitope grafting and design optimization are stages of backbone modelling done during rational vaccine design.

children.definition: Model, analyse or edit amino acid side chain conformation in protein structure, optimize side-chain packing, hydrogen bonding etc.
comment: Antibody optimisation is to optimize the antibody-interacting surface of the antigen (epitope).  Antigen optimisation is to optimize the antigen-interacting surface of the antibody (paratope). Antigen resurfacing is to resurface the antigen by varying the sequence of non-epitope regions.
Methods might use a residue rotamer library.

This includes rotamer likelihood prediction: the prediction of rotamer likelihoods for all 20 amino acid types at each position in a protein structure, where output typically includes, for each residue position, the likelihoods for the 20 amino acid types with estimated reliability of the 20 likelihoods.

children.definition: Model loop conformation in protein structures.
Build a three-dimensional protein model based on known (for example homologs) structures.
children.comment: The model might be of a whole, part or aspect of protein structure. Molecular modelling methods might use sequence-structure alignment, structural templates, molecular dynamics, energy minimisation etc.
This includes methods that predict the folding pathway(s) or non-native structural intermediates of a protein.
children.definition: Predict tertiary structure (backbone and side-chain conformation) of protein sequences.
Predict genetic code from analysis of codon usage data.
Predict a network of gene regulation.
Identify the architecture of a protein structure.
children.comment: Includes methods that try to suggest the most likely biological unit for a given protein X-ray crystal structure based on crystal symmetry and scoring of putative protein-protein interfaces.

children.definition: The simulation of molecular (typically protein) conformation using a computational model of physical forces and computer simulation.
Predict the structure of a multi-subunit protein and particularly how the subunits fit together.
The prediction of the degree of pathogenicity of a microorganism from analysis of molecular sequences.
Identify or predict causes for antibiotic resistance from molecular sequence analysis.
Identification of protein, for example from one or more peptide identifications by tandem mass spectrometry.
Identify or predict intrinsically disordered regions in proteins.
Predict a metabolic pathway.
Predict, recognise, detect or identify some properties of a biomolecule.
Find motifs shared by molecular sequences.
Detect frameshifts in DNA sequences, including frameshift sites and signals, and frameshift errors from sequencing projects.
children.comment: Methods include sequence alignment (if related sequences are available) and word-based sequence comparison.

children.definition: Detect errors in DNA sequences generated from sequencing projects).
Render a representation of a distribution that consists of group of data points plotted on a simple scale.
children.comment: Dot plots are useful when having not too many (e.g. 20) data points for each category. Example: draw a dotplot of sequence similarities identified from word-matching or character comparison.

children.definition: Find exact character or word matches between molecular sequences without full sequence alignment.
Calculate a sequence distance matrix or otherwise estimate genetic distances between molecular sequences.
Compare two or more molecular sequences, identify and remove redundant sequences based on some criteria.
Clustering of molecular sequences on the basis of their function, typically using information from an ontology of gene function, or some other measure of functional phenotype.
Build clusters of similar sequences, typically using scores from pair-wise alignment or other comparison of the sequences.
children.comment: The clusters may be output or used internally for some other purpose.

children.definition: Align molecular sequences using sequence and structural information.
Align molecular sequence(s) to sequence profile(s), or profiles to other profiles.  A profile typically represents a sequence alignment.
children.comment: A sequence profile typically represents a sequence alignment. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.

children.definition: Align exactly two molecular sequences.
children.comment: Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.

children.definition: Align more than two molecular sequences.
children.comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment, for example to incorporate sequences into an alignment, or combine several multiple alignments into a single, improved alignment.

children.definition: Locally align two or more molecular sequences.
children.comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity.

children.definition: Globally align two or more molecular sequences.
children.comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire length of the sequences.

children.definition: Align multiple sequences using relative gap costs calculated from neighbors in a supplied phylogenetic tree.
exact_synonyms: Phylogenetic tree-based multiple sequence alignment construction
children.comment: This is supposed to give a more biologically meaningful alignment than standard alignments.

children.definition: Align two or more (tpyically huge) molecular sequences that represent genomes.

comment: Includes methods that align sequence profiles (representing sequence alignments): ethods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.  See also 'Sequence alignment comparison'.
See also "Read mapping"
children.definition: Align (identify equivalent sites within) molecular sequences.
Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences that are similar to a query sequence.
Identify a representative sequence from a set of sequences, typically using scores from pair-wise alignment or other comparison of the sequences.
Compare the sequence or features of two or more genomes, for example, to find matching regions.
Compare two or more molecular sequences.
Compare the features of two genome sequences.
children.comment: Genomic elements that might be compared include genes, indels, single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), retrotransposons, tandem repeats and so on.

children.definition: Compare the feature tables of two or more molecular sequences.
Compare (typically by aligning) two molecular sequence alignments.
children.comment: See also 'Sequence profile alignment'.

children.definition: Compare two or more codon usage tables.
Compare nucleic acid tertiary structures.
Compare two or more nucleic acids to identify similarities.
Align (superimpose) exactly two molecular tertiary structures.
Align (superimpose) more than two molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment.

children.definition: Locally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity, common substructures etc.

children.definition: Globally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire structures.

Includes methods that align structural (3D) profiles or templates (representing structures or structure alignments) - including methods that perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.definition: Align (superimpose) molecular tertiary structures.
Search a database of molecular structure and retrieve structures that are similar to a query structure.
Compare protein tertiary structures.
children.comment: Methods might identify structural neighbors, find structural similarities or define a structural core.

children.definition: Compare nucleic acid tertiary structures.
Identify and remove redudancy from a set of small molecule structures.
Compare two or more molecular surfaces.
Compare two or more molecular tertiary structures.

comment: This includes sequence-to-3D-profile alignment methods, which align molecular sequence(s) to structural (3D) profile(s) or template(s) (representing a structure or structure alignment) - methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
Use this concept for methods that evaluate sequence-structure compatibility by assessing residue interactions in 3D. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.definition: Align molecular sequence to structure in 3D space (threading).
Recognize (predict and identify) known protein structural domains or folds in protein sequence(s) which (typically) are not accompanied by any significant sequence similarity to know structures.
children.comment: Methods use some type of mapping between sequence and fold, for example secondary structure prediction and alignment, profile comparison, sequence properties, homologous sequence search, kernel machines etc. Domains and folds might be taken from SCOP or CATH.

children.definition: Compare the functional properties of two or more proteins.
Compare the architecture of two or more protein structures.
Compare protein tertiary structures.
children.comment: Methods might identify structural neighbors, find structural similarities or define a structural core.

children.definition: Compare protein secondary structures.
Calculate the molecular weight of a protein (or fragments) and compare it to another protein or reference data. Generally used for protein identification.
Compare the physicochemical properties of two or more proteins (or reference data).
The analysis, using proteomics techniques, to identify proteins whose encoding genes are differentially expressed under a given experimental setup.
Compare two or more proteins (or some aspect) to identify similarities.
Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to produce a consensus tree.
children.comment: Methods typically test for topological similarity between trees using for example a congruence index.

children.definition: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to detect subtrees or supertrees.
Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to calculate distances between trees.

Mapping between gene tree nodes and species tree nodes or branches, to analyse and account for possible differences between gene histories and species histories, explaining this in terms of gene-scale events such as duplication, loss, transfer etc.
children.comment: Methods typically test for topological similarity between trees using for example a congruence index.

children.definition: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees.
children.comment: For example, to produce a consensus tree, subtrees, supertrees, calculate distances between trees or test topological similarity between trees (e.g. a congruence index) etc.

children.definition: Calculate similarity between 2 or more documents.
Cluster (group) documents on the basis of their calculated similarity.
Compare two or more scientific articles.
Map data identifiers to one another for example to establish a link between two biological databases for the purposes of data integration.
children.comment: The mapping can be achieved by comparing identifier values or some other means, e.g. exact matches to a provided sequence.

children.definition: Compare two or more ontologies, e.g. identify differences.
Compare the models or schemas used by two or more databases, or any other general comparison of databases rather than a detailed comparison of the entries themselves.
The comparison of samples from a metagenomics study, for example, by comparison of metagenome shotgun reads or assembled contig sequences, by comparison of functional profiles, or some other method.
Compare two or more things to identify similarities.
Generate the reverse and / or complement of a nucleotide sequence.
exact_synonyms: Nucleic acid sequence reverse and complement

children.definition: Generate a random sequence, for example, with a specific character composition.
Generate digest fragments for a nucleotide sequence containing restriction sites.

children.comment: This is often followed by calculation of protein fragment masses (http://edamontology.org/operation_0398).
children.definition: Cleave a protein sequence into peptide fragments (corresponding to enzymatic or chemical cleavage).
Identify base (nucleobase) sequence from a fluorescence 'trace' data generated by an automated DNA sequencer.
Generate sequences from some probabilistic model, e.g. a model that simulates evolution.
Analytical process that derives a peptide's amino acid sequence from its tandem mass spectrum (MS/MS) without the assistance of a sequence database.
Generate a molecular sequence by some means.
Merge two or more (typically overlapping) molecular sequences.
Translate a DNA sequence into protein.
Transcribe a nucleotide sequence into mRNA sequence(s).
Back-translate a protein sequence into DNA.
Convert a molecular sequence from one type to another.
Mutate a molecular sequence a specified amount or shuffle it to produce a randomised sequence with the same overall composition.
Mask characters in a molecular sequence (replacing those characters with a mask character).
children.comment: For example, SNPs or repeats in a DNA sequence might be masked.

children.definition: Cut (remove) the end from a molecular sequence.
children.comment: This includesennd trimmingTrim sequences (typically from an automated DNA sequencer) to remove misleading ends.For example trim polyA tails, introns and primer sequence flanking the sequence of amplified exons, or other unwanted sequence.trimming to a reference sequence,Trim sequences (typically from an automated DNA sequencer) to remove the sequence ends that extend beyond an assembled reference sequence.vector trimmingTrim sequences (typically from an automated DNA sequencer) to remove sequence-specific end regions, typically contamination from vector sequences.

children.definition: Remove forward and/or reverse primers from nucleic acid sequences (typically PCR products).
Cut (remove) characters or a region from a molecular sequence.
Create (or remove) restriction sites in sequences, for example using silent mutations.

Perform basic (non-analytical) operations on a report or file of sequences (which might include features), such as file concatenation, removal or ordering of sequences, creation of subset or a new file of sequences.
Edit or change a molecular sequence, either randomly or specifically.
Calculate sequence complexity, for example to find low-complexity regions in sequences.
Calculate sequence ambiguity, for example identity regions in protein or nucleotide sequences with many ambiguity codes.
Analyse repeat sequence organisation such as periodicity.
Calculate a density plot (of base composition) for a nucleotide sequence.
Count k-mers (substrings of length k) in DNA sequence data.
children.comment: k-mer counting is used in genome and transcriptome assembly, metagenomic sequencing, and for error correction of sequence reads.

children.definition: Calculate character or word composition or frequency of a molecular sequence.
Find (and possibly render) short repetitive subsequences (repeat sequences) in (typically nucleotide) sequences.
Analyse repeat sequence organisation such as periodicity.
Find and/or analyse repeat sequences in (typically nucleotide) sequences.
children.comment: Repeat sequences include tandem repeats, inverted or palindromic repeats, DNA microsatellites (Simple Sequence Repeats or SSRs), interspersed repeats, maximal duplications and reverse, complemented and reverse complemented repeats etc. Repeat units can be exact or imperfect, in tandem or dispersed, of specified or unspecified length.

children.definition: Discover new motifs or conserved patterns in sequences or sequence alignments (de-novo discovery).
children.comment: Motifs and patterns might be conserved or over-represented (occur with improbable frequency).

children.definition: Find (scan for) known motifs, patterns and regular expressions in molecular sequence(s).
Predict, recognise and identify positional features in molecular sequences such as key functional sites or regions.
children.comment: Look at "Protein feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_3092) and "Nucleic acid feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_0415) in case more specific terms are needed.

children.definition: Discover new motifs or conserved patterns in sequences or sequence alignments (de-novo discovery).
children.comment: Motifs and patterns might be conserved or over-represented (occur with improbable frequency).

children.definition: Find (scan for) known motifs, patterns and regular expressions in molecular sequence(s).
Find motifs shared by molecular sequences.
Analyse molecular sequence motifs.
Find motifs shared by molecular sequences.
Detect frameshifts in DNA sequences, including frameshift sites and signals, and frameshift errors from sequencing projects.
children.comment: Methods include sequence alignment (if related sequences are available) and word-based sequence comparison.

children.definition: Detect errors in DNA sequences generated from sequencing projects).
Render a representation of a distribution that consists of group of data points plotted on a simple scale.
children.comment: Dot plots are useful when having not too many (e.g. 20) data points for each category. Example: draw a dotplot of sequence similarities identified from word-matching or character comparison.

children.definition: Find exact character or word matches between molecular sequences without full sequence alignment.
Calculate a sequence distance matrix or otherwise estimate genetic distances between molecular sequences.
Compare two or more molecular sequences, identify and remove redundant sequences based on some criteria.
Clustering of molecular sequences on the basis of their function, typically using information from an ontology of gene function, or some other measure of functional phenotype.
Build clusters of similar sequences, typically using scores from pair-wise alignment or other comparison of the sequences.
children.comment: The clusters may be output or used internally for some other purpose.

children.definition: Align molecular sequences using sequence and structural information.
Align molecular sequence(s) to sequence profile(s), or profiles to other profiles.  A profile typically represents a sequence alignment.
children.comment: A sequence profile typically represents a sequence alignment. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.

children.definition: Align exactly two molecular sequences.
children.comment: Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.

children.definition: Align more than two molecular sequences.
children.comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment, for example to incorporate sequences into an alignment, or combine several multiple alignments into a single, improved alignment.

children.definition: Locally align two or more molecular sequences.
children.comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity.

children.comment: This is supposed to give a more biologically meaningful alignment than standard alignments.

Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences that are similar to a query sequence.
Identify a representative sequence from a set of sequences, typically using scores from pair-wise alignment or other comparison of the sequences.

Compare two or more molecular sequences.
Compare the features of two genome sequences.
children.comment: Genomic elements that might be compared include genes, indels, single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), retrotransposons, tandem repeats and so on.

Compare (typically by aligning) two molecular sequence alignments.
children.comment: See also 'Sequence profile alignment'.

children.definition: Generate some type of sequence profile (for example a hidden Markov model) from a sequence alignment.
Evaluate molecular sequence alignment accuracy.
children.comment: Evaluation might be purely sequence-based or use structural information.

children.definition: Analyse character conservation in a molecular sequence alignment, for example to derive a consensus sequence.
children.comment: Use this concept for methods that calculate substitution rates, estimate relative site variability, identify sites with biased properties, derive a consensus sequence, or identify highly conserved or very poorly conserved sites, regions, blocks etc.

children.definition: Analyse correlations between sites in a molecular sequence alignment.
children.comment: This is typically done to identify possible covarying positions and predict contacts or structural constraints in protein structures.

children.definition: Refine an existing sequence alignment.
Analyse a molecular sequence alignment.
Identify or screen for 3D structural motifs in protein structure(s).
children.comment: This includes conserved substructures and conserved geometry, such as spatial arrangement of secondary structure or protein backbone. Methods might use structure alignment, structural templates, searches for similar electrostatic potential and molecular surface shape, surface-mapping of phylogenetic information etc.

children.definition: Decompose a structure into compact or globular fragments (protein peeling).
Identify structural domains in a protein structure from first principles (for example calculations on structural compactness).
Predict super-secondary structure of protein sequence(s).
children.comment: Super-secondary structures include leucine zippers, coiled coils, Helix-Turn-Helix etc.

children.definition: Predict and/or classify transmembrane proteins or transmembrane (helical) domains or regions in protein sequences.
Predict helical secondary structure of protein sequences.
Predict turn structure (for example beta hairpin turns) of protein sequences.
Predict open coils, non-regular secondary structure and intrinsically disordered / unstructured regions of protein sequences.
Predict secondary structure of protein sequences.
children.comment: Methods might use amino acid composition, local sequence information, multiple sequence alignments, physicochemical features, estimated energy content, statistical algorithms, hidden Markov models, support vector machines, kernel machines, neural networks etc.

comment: This includes sequence-to-3D-profile alignment methods, which align molecular sequence(s) to structural (3D) profile(s) or template(s) (representing a structure or structure alignment) - methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
Use this concept for methods that evaluate sequence-structure compatibility by assessing residue interactions in 3D. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.definition: Align molecular sequence to structure in 3D space (threading).
Recognize (predict and identify) known protein structural domains or folds in protein sequence(s) which (typically) are not accompanied by any significant sequence similarity to know structures.
children.comment: Methods use some type of mapping between sequence and fold, for example secondary structure prediction and alignment, profile comparison, sequence properties, homologous sequence search, kernel machines etc. Domains and folds might be taken from SCOP or CATH.

children.definition: Predict antigenic determinant sites (epitopes) in protein sequences.
children.comment: Epitope mapping is commonly done during vaccine design.

children.definition: Predict post-translation modification sites in protein sequences.
children.comment: Methods might predict sites of methylation, N-terminal myristoylation, N-terminal acetylation, sumoylation, palmitoylation, phosphorylation, sulfation, glycosylation, glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) modification sites (GPI lipid anchor signals) etc.

children.definition: Detect or predict signal peptides and signal peptide cleavage sites in protein sequences.
children.comment: Methods might use sequence motifs and features, amino acid composition, profiles, machine-learned classifiers, etc.

children.definition: Predict or detect RNA-binding sites in protein sequences.
Predict or detect DNA-binding sites in protein sequences.
Predict or detect RNA and DNA-binding binding sites in protein sequences.
children.comment: This includes methods that predict and optimise zinc finger protein domains for DNA/RNA binding (for example for transcription factors and nucleases).

children.definition: Identify or predict protein-protein binding sites.
Predict or detect active sites in proteins; the region of an enzyme which binds a substrate bind and catalyses a reaction.
Predict or detect ligand-binding sites in proteins; a region of a protein which reversibly binds a ligand for some biochemical purpose, such as transport or regulation of protein function.
Predict or detect metal ion-binding sites in proteins.
Identify or predict catalytic residues, active sites or other ligand-binding sites in protein sequences or structures.
Detect or predict cleavage sites (enzymatic or chemical) in protein sequences.
Predict cysteine bonding state and disulfide bond partners in protein sequences.
Identify or predict intrinsically disordered regions in proteins.
Predict adhesins in protein sequences.
children.comment: An adhesin is a cell-surface component that facilitate the adherence of a microorganism to a cell or surface. They are important virulence factors during establishment of infection and thus are targetted during vaccine development approaches that seek to block adhesin function and prevent adherence to host cell.

children.definition: Predict, recognise and identify positional features in proteins from analysing protein sequences or structures.
children.comment: Features includes functional sites or regions, secondary structure, structural domains and so on. Methods might use fingerprints, motifs, profiles, hidden Markov models, sequence alignment etc to provide a mapping of a query protein sequence to a discriminatory element. This includes methods that search a secondary protein database (Prosite, Blocks, ProDom, Prints, Pfam etc.) to assign a protein sequence(s) to a known protein family or group.

children.definition: Predict super-secondary structure of protein sequence(s).
children.comment: Super-secondary structures include leucine zippers, coiled coils, Helix-Turn-Helix etc.

children.definition: Predict and/or classify transmembrane proteins or transmembrane (helical) domains or regions in protein sequences.
Predict helical secondary structure of protein sequences.
Predict turn structure (for example beta hairpin turns) of protein sequences.
Predict open coils, non-regular secondary structure and intrinsically disordered / unstructured regions of protein sequences.
Predict secondary structure of protein sequences.
children.comment: Methods might use amino acid composition, local sequence information, multiple sequence alignments, physicochemical features, estimated energy content, statistical algorithms, hidden Markov models, support vector machines, kernel machines, neural networks etc.

children.definition: Predict contacts, non-covalent interactions and distance (constraints) between amino acids in protein sequences.
children.comment: Methods usually involve multiple sequence alignment analysis.

comment: This includes sequence-to-3D-profile alignment methods, which align molecular sequence(s) to structural (3D) profile(s) or template(s) (representing a structure or structure alignment) - methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
Use this concept for methods that evaluate sequence-structure compatibility by assessing residue interactions in 3D. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.definition: Align molecular sequence to structure in 3D space (threading).
Recognize (predict and identify) known protein structural domains or folds in protein sequence(s) which (typically) are not accompanied by any significant sequence similarity to know structures.
children.comment: Methods use some type of mapping between sequence and fold, for example secondary structure prediction and alignment, profile comparison, sequence properties, homologous sequence search, kernel machines etc. Domains and folds might be taken from SCOP or CATH.

children.definition: Predict tertiary structure of protein sequence(s) without homologs of known structure.
Model protein backbone conformation.
comment: Methods might require a preliminary C(alpha) trace.
Scaffold selection, scaffold search, epitope grafting and design optimization are stages of backbone modelling done during rational vaccine design.

children.definition: Model, analyse or edit amino acid side chain conformation in protein structure, optimize side-chain packing, hydrogen bonding etc.
comment: Antibody optimisation is to optimize the antibody-interacting surface of the antigen (epitope).  Antigen optimisation is to optimize the antigen-interacting surface of the antibody (paratope). Antigen resurfacing is to resurface the antigen by varying the sequence of non-epitope regions.
Methods might use a residue rotamer library.

This includes rotamer likelihood prediction: the prediction of rotamer likelihoods for all 20 amino acid types at each position in a protein structure, where output typically includes, for each residue position, the likelihoods for the 20 amino acid types with estimated reliability of the 20 likelihoods.

children.definition: Model loop conformation in protein structures.
Build a three-dimensional protein model based on known (for example homologs) structures.
children.comment: The model might be of a whole, part or aspect of protein structure. Molecular modelling methods might use sequence-structure alignment, structural templates, molecular dynamics, energy minimisation etc.
This includes methods that predict the folding pathway(s) or non-native structural intermediates of a protein.
children.definition: Predict tertiary structure (backbone and side-chain conformation) of protein sequences.
Analyse a protein sequence (using methods that are only applicable to protein sequences).
Detect frameshifts in DNA sequences, including frameshift sites and signals, and frameshift errors from sequencing projects.
children.comment: Methods include sequence alignment (if related sequences are available) and word-based sequence comparison.

children.definition: Identify insertion, deletion and duplication events from a sequence alignment.
children.comment: Tools might use a genetic algorithm, quartet-mapping, bootscanning, graphical methods, random forest model and so on.

children.definition: Find single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) - single nucleotide change in base positions - between sequences. Typically done for sequences from a high-throughput sequencing experiment that differ from a reference genome and which might, especially by reference to population frequency or functional data, indicate a polymorphism.
children.comment: This includes functional SNPs for large-scale genotyping purposes, disease-associated non-synonymous SNPs etc.

children.definition: Detect, identify and map mutations, such as single nucleotide polymorphisms, short indels and structural variants, in multiple DNA sequences. Typically the alignment and comparison of the fluorescent traces produced by DNA sequencing hardware, to study genomic alterations.
comment: Methods often utilise a database of aligned reads.
Somatic variant calling is the detection of variations established in somatic cells and hence not inherited as a germ line variant.
Variant detection

children.definition: Detect vector sequences in nucleotide sequence, typically by comparison to a set of known vector sequences.
Predict RNA secondary structure (for example knots, pseudoknots, alternative structures etc).
children.comment: Methods might use RNA motifs, predicted intermolecular contacts, or RNA sequence-structure compatibility (inverse RNA folding).

children.definition: Find (and possibly render) short repetitive subsequences (repeat sequences) in (typically nucleotide) sequences.
Detect or predict transposons, retrotransposons / retrotransposition signatures etc.
Detect polyA signals in nucleotide sequences.
Detect quadruplex-forming motifs in nucleotide sequences.
children.comment: Quadruplex (4-stranded) structures are formed by guanine-rich regions and are implicated in various important biological processes and as therapeutic targets.

children.definition: Find CpG rich regions in a nucleotide sequence or isochores in genome sequences.
children.comment: An isochore is long region (> 3 KB) of DNA with very uniform GC content, in contrast to the rest of the genome. Isochores tend tends to have more genes, higher local melting or denaturation temperatures, and different flexibility. Methods might calculate fractional GC content or variation of GC content, predict methylation status of CpG islands etc. This includes methods that visualise CpG rich regions in a nucleotide sequence, for example plot isochores in a genome sequence.

children.definition: Find and identify restriction enzyme cleavage sites (restriction sites) in (typically) DNA sequences, for example to generate a restriction map.
Identify or predict nucleosome exclusion sequences (nucleosome free regions) in DNA.
Identify putative protein-binding regions in a genome sequence from analysis of Chip-sequencing data or ChIP-on-chip data.
children.comment: Chip-sequencing combines chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) with massively parallel DNA sequencing to generate a set of reads, which are aligned to a genome sequence.  The enriched areas contain the binding sites of DNA-associated proteins.  For example, a transcription factor binding site. ChIP-on-chip in contrast combines chromatin immunoprecipitation ('ChIP') with microarray ('chip').  "Peak-pair calling" is similar to "Peak calling" in the context of ChIP-exo.

children.definition: Identify binding sites in nucleic acid sequences that are statistically significantly differentially bound between sample groups.
Predict, recognise and identify features in nucleotide sequences such as functional sites or regions, typically by scanning for known motifs, patterns and regular expressions.
comment: Methods typically involve scanning for known motifs, patterns and regular expressions.

This is placeholder but does not comprehensively include all child concepts - please inspect other concepts under "Nucleic acid sequence analysis" for example "Gene prediction", for other feature detection operations.

children.definition: Infer haplotypes, either alleles at multiple loci that are transmitted together on the same chromosome, or a set of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) on a single chromatid that are statistically associated.
children.comment: Haplotype inference can help in population genetic studies and the identification of complex disease genes, , and is typically based on aligned single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) fragments. Haplotype comparison is a useful way to characterize the genetic variation between individuals. An individual's haplotype describes which nucleotide base occurs at each position for a set of common SNPs. Tools might use combinatorial functions (for example parsimony) or a likelihood function or model with optimisation such as minimum error correction (MEC) model, expectation-maximisation algorithm (EM), genetic algorithm or Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC).

children.definition: Generate a genetic (linkage) map of a DNA sequence (typically a chromosome) showing the relative positions of genetic markers based on estimation of non-physical distances.
comment: Mapping involves ordering genetic loci along a chromosome and estimating the physical distance between loci. A genetic map shows the relative (not physical) position of known genes and genetic markers.
This includes mapping of the genetic architecture of dynamic complex traits (functional mapping), e.g. by characterisation of the underlying quantitative trait loci (QTLs) or nucleotides (QTNs).

children.definition: Calculate linkage disequilibrium; the non-random association of alleles or polymorphisms at two or more loci (not necessarily on the same chromosome).
children.comment: Linkage disequilibrium is identified where a combination of alleles (or genetic markers) occurs more or less frequently in a population than expected by chance formation of haplotypes.

children.definition: Analyse genetic linkage.
children.comment: For example, estimate how close two genes are on a chromosome by calculating how often they are transmitted together to an offspring, ascertain whether two genes are linked and parental linkage, calculate linkage map distance etc.

children.definition: Calculate codon usage statistics and create a codon usage table.
Compare two or more codon usage tables.
Identify and plot third base position variability in a nucleotide sequence.
Predict genetic code from analysis of codon usage data.
Identify a plausible model of DNA substitution that explains a molecular (DNA or protein) sequence alignment.
Calculate codon usage bias, e.g. generate a codon usage bias plot.
Calculate the differences in codon usage fractions between two sequences, sets of sequences, codon usage tables etc.
The development and use of mathematical models and systems analysis for the description of ecological processes, and applications such as the sustainable management of resources.
Analyse codon usage in molecular sequences or process codon usage data (e.g. a codon usage table).
Perform in-silico (virtual) PCR.
Sequence assembly by combining fragments using an existing backbone sequence, typically a reference genome.
children.comment: The final sequence will resemble the backbone sequence. Mapping assemblers are usually much faster and less memory intensive than de-novo assemblers.

children.definition: Sequence assembly by combining fragments without the aid of a reference sequence or genome.
children.comment: De-novo assemblers are much slower and more memory intensive than mapping assemblers.

children.definition: The process of assembling many short DNA sequences together such thay they represent the original chromosomes from which the DNA originated.
Sequence assembly for EST sequences (transcribed mRNA).
children.comment: Assemblers must handle (or be complicated by) alternative splicing, trans-splicing, single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP), recoding, and post-transcriptional modification.

children.definition: Reconstruction of a sequence assembly in a localised area.
Fill the gaps in a sequence assembly (scaffold) by merging in additional sequences.
children.comment: Different techniques are used to generate gap sequences to connect contigs, depending on the size of the gap. For small (5-20kb) gaps, PCR amplification and sequencing is used.  For large (>20kb) gaps, fragments are cloned (e.g. in BAC (Bacterial artificial chromosomes) vectors) and then sequenced.

children.definition: Link together a non-contiguous series of genomic sequences into a scaffold, consisting of sequences separated by gaps of known length.  The sequences that are linked are typically typically contigs; contiguous sequences corresponding to read overlaps.
children.comment: Scaffold may be positioned along a chromosome physical map to create a "golden path".

children.definition: Analyse sequencing data from experiments aiming to selectively sequence the coding regions of the genome.
Infer a transcriptome sequence by analysis of short sequence reads.
Construction of a single sequence assembly of all reads from different samples, typically as part of a comparative metagenomic analysis.
Combine (align and merge) overlapping fragments of a DNA sequence to reconstruct the original sequence.
children.comment: For example, assemble overlapping reads from paired-end sequencers into contigs (a contiguous sequence corresponding to read overlaps). Or assemble contigs, for example ESTs and genomic DNA fragments, depending on the detected fragment overlaps.

children.definition: Annotate a genome sequence with terms from a controlled vocabulary.
The process of assembling many short DNA sequences together such thay they represent the original chromosomes from which the DNA originated.
Align two or more (tpyically huge) molecular sequences that represent genomes.
Compare the features of two genome sequences.
children.comment: Genomic elements that might be compared include genes, indels, single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), retrotransposons, tandem repeats and so on.

children.definition: Measure the overall level of methyl cytosines in a genome from analysis of experimental data, typically from chromatographic methods and methyl accepting capacity assay.
Visualise, format or render a nucleic acid sequence that is part of (and in context of) a complete genome sequence.
Compare the sequence or features of two or more genomes, for example, to find matching regions.
Generate an index of a genome sequence.
children.comment: Many sequence alignment tasks involving many or very large sequences rely on a precomputed index of the sequence to accelerate the alignment.  The Burrows-Wheeler Transform (BWT) is a permutation of the genome based on a suffix array algorithm.  A suffix array consists of the lexicographically sorted list of suffixes of a genome.

children.definition: Detects chimeric sequences (chimeras) from a sequence alignment.
Predict splicing alternatives or transcript isoforms from analysis of sequence data.
Identify, predict or analyse splice sites in nucleotide sequences.
children.comment: Methods might require a pre-mRNA or genomic DNA sequence.

children.definition: Predict, analyse, characterize or model splice sites, splicing events and so on, typically by comparing multiple nucleic acid sequences.
Find operons (operators, promoters and genes) in bacteria genes.
Predict translation initiation sites, possibly by searching a database of sites.
Predict protein-coding regions (CDS or exon) or open reading frames in nucleotide sequences.
Predict selenocysteine insertion sequence (SECIS) in a DNA sequence.
children.comment: SECIS elements are around 60 nucleotides in length with a stem-loop structure directs the cell to translate UGA codons as selenocysteines.

children.definition: Identify or predict transcription factor binding sites in DNA sequences.
Identify or predict exonic splicing enhancers (ESE) in exons.
children.comment: An exonic splicing enhancer (ESE) is 6-base DNA sequence motif in an exon that enhances or directs splicing of pre-mRNA or hetero-nuclear RNA (hnRNA) into mRNA.

children.definition: Identify or predict whole promoters or promoter elements (transcription start sites, RNA polymerase binding site, transcription factor binding sites, promoter enhancers etc) in DNA sequences.
children.comment: Methods might recognize CG content, CpG islands, splice sites, polyA signals etc.

children.definition: Identify, predict or analyse cis-regulatory elements  in DNA sequences (TATA box, Pribnow box, SOS box, CAAT box, CCAAT box, operator etc.) or in RNA sequences (e.g. riboswitches).
children.comment: Cis-regulatory elements (cis-elements) regulate the expression of genes located on the same strand from which the element was transcribed. Cis-elements are found in the 5' promoter region of the gene, in an intron, or in the 3' untranslated region. Cis-elements are often binding sites of one or more trans-acting factors. They also occur in RNA sequences, e.g. a riboswitch is a region of an mRNA molecule that bind a small target molecule that regulates the gene's activity.

children.definition: Identify or predict microRNA sequences (miRNA) and precursors or microRNA targets / binding sites in a DNA sequence.
Assess binding specificity of putative siRNA sequence(s), for example for a functional assay, typically with respect to designing specific siRNA sequences.
Identify or predict siRNA duplexes in RNA.
Identify or predict functional RNA sequences with a gene regulatory role (trans-regulatory elements) or targets.
children.comment: Trans-regulatory elements regulate genes distant from the gene from which they were transcribed.

children.definition: Identify matrix/scaffold attachment regions (MARs/SARs) in DNA sequences.
children.comment: MAR/SAR sites often flank a gene or gene cluster and are found nearby cis-regulatory sequences. They might contribute to transcription regulation.

comment: This includes comparative genomics approaches that identify common, conserved (homologous) or synonymous transcriptional regulatory elements.  For example cross-species comparison of transcription factor binding sites (TFBS). Methods might analyse co-regulated or co-expressed genes, or sets of oppositely expressed genes.

This includes promoters, enhancers, silencers and boundary elements / insulators, regulatory protein or transcription factor binding sites etc. Methods might be specific to a particular genome and use motifs, word-based / grammatical methods, position-specific frequency matrices, discriminative pattern analysis etc.
children.definition: Identify or predict transcriptional regulatory motifs, patterns, elements or regions in DNA sequences.
Identify or predict tRNA genes in genomic sequences (tRNA).
Prediction of genes or gene components from first principles, i.e. without reference to existing genes.
Prediction of genes or gene components by reference to homologous genes.

comment: Includes methods that predict whole gene structure using a combination of multiple methods to achieve better predictions.
Methods for gene prediction might be ab initio, based on phylogenetic comparisons, use motifs, sequence features, support vector machine, alignment etc.
children.definition: Detect, predict and identify genes or components of genes in DNA sequences, including promoters, coding regions, splice sites, etc.
Detects chimeric sequences (chimeras) from a sequence alignment.
children.comment: A chimera includes regions from two or more phylogenetically distinct sequences. They are usually artifacts of PCR and are thought to occur when a prematurely terminated amplicon reanneals to another DNA strand and is subsequently copied to completion in later PCR cycles.

children.definition: Detect recombination (hotspots and coldspots) and identify recombination breakpoints in a sequence alignment.
children.comment: Tools might use a genetic algorithm, quartet-mapping, bootscanning, graphical methods, random forest model and so on.

children.definition: Design or predict oligonucleotide primers for PCR and DNA amplification etc.
narrow_synonyms: PCR primer design (based on gene structure)
PCR primer design (for gene transcription profiling)
PCR primer design (for large scale sequencing)
comment: Primer design involves predicting or selecting primers that are specific to a provided PCR template. Primers can be designed with certain properties such as size of product desired, primer size etc. The output might be a minimal or overlapping primer set.

This includes predicting primers based on gene structure, promoters, exon-exon junctions, predicting primers that are conserved across multiple genomes or species, primers for for gene transcription profiling,  for genotyping polymorphisms, for example single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs),  for large scale sequencing, or for methylation PCRs.

children.definition: Predict and/or optimize oligonucleotide probes for DNA microarrays, for example for transcription profiling of genes, or for genomes and gene families.
Predict oligonucleotide primers or probes.
Predict or optimise RNA sequences (sequence pools) with likely secondary and tertiary structure for in vitro selection.
Predict or optimise DNA to elicit (via DNA vaccination) an immunological response.
A technique whereby molecules with desired properties and function are isolated from libraries of random molecules, through iterative cycles of selection, amplification, and mutagenesis.
Design (or predict) nucleic acid sequences with specific chemical or physical properties.
Evaluate a DNA sequence assembly, typically for purposes of quality control.
Identify and filter a (typically large) sequence data set to remove sequences from contaminants in the sample that was sequenced.
Pre-process sequence reads to ensure (or improve) quality and reliability.
children.comment: For example process paired end reads to trim low quality ends remove short sequences, identify sequence inserts, detect chimeric reads, or remove low quality sequnces including vector, adaptor, low complexity and contaminant sequences. Sequences might come from genomic DNA library, EST libraries, SSH library and so on.

children.definition: Variant filtering is used to eliminate false positive variants based for example on base calling quality, strand and position information, and mapping info.
Raw sequence data quality control.
children.comment: Analyse raw sequence data from a sequencing pipeline and identify (and possiby fix) problems.

children.definition: The mapping of methylation sites in a DNA (genome) sequence.  Typically, the mapping of high-throughput bisulfite reads to the reference genome.
children.comment: Bisulfite mapping follows high-throughput sequencing of DNA which has undergone bisulfite treatment followed by PCR amplification; unmethylated cytosines are specifically converted to thymine, allowing the methylation status of cytosine in the DNA to be detected.

children.definition: Measure the overall level of methyl cytosines in a genome from analysis of experimental data, typically from chromatographic methods and methyl accepting capacity assay.
Analysing the DNA methylation of specific genes or regions of interest.
Identify and assess specific genes or regulatory regions of interest that are differentially methylated.
The determination of cytosine methylation status of specific positions in a nucleic acid sequences (usually reads from a bisulfite sequencing experiment).
Analyse cytosine methylation states in nucleic acid sequences.
A varient of oligonucleotide mapping where a read is mapped to two separate locations because of possible structural variation.
Align short oligonucleotide sequences (reads) to a larger (genomic) sequence.
children.comment: The purpose of read mapping is to identify the location of sequenced fragments within a reference genome and assumes that there is, in fact, at least local similarity between the fragment and reference sequences.

children.definition: Pre-process sequence reads to ensure (or improve) quality and reliability.
children.comment: For example process paired end reads to trim low quality ends remove short sequences, identify sequence inserts, detect chimeric reads, or remove low quality sequnces including vector, adaptor, low complexity and contaminant sequences. Sequences might come from genomic DNA library, EST libraries, SSH library and so on.

children.definition: Analyse mapping density (read depth) of (typically) short reads from sequencing platforms, for example, to detect deletions and duplications.
Analyze read counts from RNA-seq experiments.
Analyze time series data from an RNA-seq experiment.
Analyze data from RNA-seq experiments.
Counting and summarising the number of short sequence reads that map to genomic features.
An operation which groups reads or contigs and assigns them to operational taxonomic units.
children.comment: Binning methods use one or a combination of compositional features or sequence similarity.

children.definition: Assigning sequence reads to separate groups / files based on their index tag (sample origin).
children.comment: NGS sequence runs are often performed with multiple samples pooled together.  In such cases, an index tag (or "barcode") - a unique sequence of between 6 and 12bp - is ligated to each sample's genetic material so that the sequence reads from different samples can be identified. The process of demultiplexing (dividing sequence reads into separate files for each index tag/sample) may be performed automatically by the sequencing hardware. Alternatively the reads may be lumped together in one file with barcodes still attached, requiring you to do the splitting using software. In such cases, a "mapping" file is used which indicates which barcodes correspond to which samples.

children.definition: The processing of reads from high-throughput sequencing machines.
Analyse DNA sequences in order to identify a DNA 'barcode'; marker genes or any short fragment(s) of DNA that are useful to diagnose the taxa of biological organisms.
Estimate the frequencies of different species from analysis of the molecular sequences, typically of DNA recovered from environmental samples.
Analyse DNA sequences in order to determine an individual's DNA characteristics, for example in criminal forensics, parentage testing and so on.
The identification of changes in DNA sequence or chromosome structure, usually in the context of diagnostic tests for disease, or to study ancestry or phylogeny.
children.comment: This can include indirect methods which reveal the results of genetic changes, such as RNA analysis to indicate gene expression, or biochemical analysis to identify expressed proteins.

children.definition: The detection of genetic selection, or (the end result of) the process by which certain traits become more prevalent in a species than other traits.
Analyse a nucleic acid sequence (using methods that are only applicable to nucleic acid sequences).
Identify and plot third base position variability in a nucleotide sequence.
Calculate the hydrophobic moment of a peptide sequence and recognize amphiphilicity.
children.comment: Hydrophobic moment is a peptides hydrophobicity measured for different angles of rotation.

children.definition: Render a representation of a distribution that consists of group of data points plotted on a simple scale.
children.comment: Dot plots are useful when having not too many (e.g. 20) data points for each category. Example: draw a dotplot of sequence similarities identified from word-matching or character comparison.

children.definition: Calculate a density plot (of base composition) for a nucleotide sequence.
Render and visualise a DNA sequence assembly.
Visualise, format or render a nucleic acid sequence that is part of (and in context of) a complete genome sequence.
Visualise, format or render a molecular sequence or sequences such as a sequence alignment, possibly with sequence features or properties shown.
Align molecular sequences using sequence and structural information.
Align molecular sequence(s) to sequence profile(s), or profiles to other profiles.  A profile typically represents a sequence alignment.
children.comment: A sequence profile typically represents a sequence alignment. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.

children.definition: Align exactly two molecular sequences.
children.comment: Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.

children.definition: Align more than two molecular sequences.
children.comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment, for example to incorporate sequences into an alignment, or combine several multiple alignments into a single, improved alignment.

children.definition: Locally align two or more molecular sequences.
children.comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity.

children.definition: Globally align two or more molecular sequences.
children.comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire length of the sequences.

children.definition: Align multiple sequences using relative gap costs calculated from neighbors in a supplied phylogenetic tree.
exact_synonyms: Phylogenetic tree-based multiple sequence alignment construction
children.comment: This is supposed to give a more biologically meaningful alignment than standard alignments.

children.definition: Align two or more (tpyically huge) molecular sequences that represent genomes.

comment: Includes methods that align sequence profiles (representing sequence alignments): ethods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.  See also 'Sequence alignment comparison'.
See also "Read mapping"
children.definition: Align (identify equivalent sites within) molecular sequences.
Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences that are similar to a query sequence.
Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences with a specified property, typically a physicochemical or compositional property.
Search a sequence database by sequence comparison and retrieve similar sequences.sequences matching a given sequence motif or pattern, such as a Prosite pattern or regular expression.
children.comment: This excludes direct retrieval methods (e.g. the dbfetch program).

children.definition: Phylogenetic tree construction from molecular sequences.
children.comment: Methods typically compare multiple molecular sequence and estimate evolutionary distances and relationships to infer gene families or make functional predictions.

children.definition: Perform basic (non-analytical) operations on a report or file of sequences (which might include features), such as file concatenation, removal or ordering of sequences, creation of subset or a new file of sequences.
Classify variants based on their potential effect on genes, especially functional effects on the expressed proteins.
children.comment: Variants are typically classified by their position (intronic, exonic, etc.) in a gene transcript and (for variants in coding exons) by their effect on the protein sequence (synonymous, non-synonymous, frameshifting, etc.)

children.definition: Classifiication (typically of molecular sequences) by assignment to some taxonomic hierarchy.
Assign molecular sequence(s) to a group or category.
The prediction of the degree of pathogenicity of a microorganism from analysis of molecular sequences.
Identify or predict causes for antibiotic resistance from molecular sequence analysis.
Analyse one or more known molecular sequences.
Predict antigenicity, allergenicity / immunogenicity, allergic cross-reactivity etc of peptides and proteins.
comment: Immunological system are cellular or humoral. In vaccine design to induces a cellular immune response, methods must search for antigens that can be recognized by the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules present in T lymphocytes.  If a humoral response is required, antigens for B cells must be identified.
This includes methods that generate a graphical rendering of antigenicity of a protein, such as a Hopp and Woods plot.
This is usually done in the development of peptide-specific antibodies or multi-epitope vaccines. Methods might use sequence data (for example motifs) and / or structural data.

children.definition: Analyse a network of protein interactions.
Predict the interactions of proteins with other proteins.
Predict a network of protein interactions.

children.comment: Includes analysis of raw experimental protein-protein interaction data from for example yeast two-hybrid analysis, protein microarrays, immunoaffinity chromatography followed by mass spectrometry, phage display etc.
children.definition: Analyse the interactions of proteins with other proteins.
Predict DNA-binding proteins.
Predict RNA-binding proteins.
Analyse the interaction of protein with nucleic acids, e.g. RNA or DNA-binding sites, interfaces etc.
Detect or predict signal peptides and signal peptide cleavage sites in protein sequences.
children.comment: Methods might use sequence motifs and features, amino acid composition, profiles, machine-learned classifiers, etc.

children.definition: Predict or detect RNA-binding sites in protein sequences.
Predict or detect DNA-binding sites in protein sequences.
Predict or detect RNA and DNA-binding binding sites in protein sequences.
children.comment: This includes methods that predict and optimise zinc finger protein domains for DNA/RNA binding (for example for transcription factors and nucleases).

children.definition: Identify or predict protein-protein binding sites.
Predict or detect active sites in proteins; the region of an enzyme which binds a substrate bind and catalyses a reaction.
Predict or detect ligand-binding sites in proteins; a region of a protein which reversibly binds a ligand for some biochemical purpose, such as transport or regulation of protein function.
Predict or detect metal ion-binding sites in proteins.
Identify or predict catalytic residues, active sites or other ligand-binding sites in protein sequences or structures.

Virtual screening is used in drug discovery to identify potential drug compounds.  It involves searching libraries of small molecules in order to identify those molecules which are most likely to bind to a drug target (typically a protein receptor or enzyme).
children.comment: Virtual screening is widely used for lead identification, lead optimization, and scaffold hopping during drug design and discovery.

children.definition: Model protein-ligand (for example protein-peptide) binding using comparative modelling or other techniques.
comment: Methods aim to predict the position and orientation of a ligand bound to a protein receptor or enzyme.

Virtual screening is used in drug discovery to search libraries of small molecules in order to identify those molecules which are most likely to bind to a drug target (typically a protein receptor or enzyme).

children.definition: Model or simulate protein-protein binding using comparative modelling or other techniques.
Model the structure of a protein in complex with a small molecule or another macromolecule.
children.comment: This includes protein-protein interactions, protein-nucleic acid, protein-ligand binding etc. Methods might predict whether the molecules are likely to bind in vivo, their conformation when bound, the strength of the interaction, possible mutations to achieve bonding and so on.

children.definition: Compare the functional properties of two or more proteins.
Predict the subcellular localisation of a protein sequence.
children.comment: The prediction might include subcellular localisation (nuclear, cytoplasmic, mitochondrial, chloroplast, plastid, membrane etc) or export (extracellular proteins) of a protein.

children.definition: Predict the biological or biochemical role of a protein, or other aspects of a protein function.
children.comment: For functional properties that can be mapped to a sequence, use 'Sequence feature detection (protein)' instead.

children.definition: Predict and/or classify transmembrane proteins or transmembrane (helical) domains or regions in protein sequences.
Visualise transmembrane proteins, typically the transmembrane regions within a sequence.
Analyse transmembrane protein(s), typically by processing sequence and / or structural data, and write an informative report for example about the protein and its transmembrane domains / regions.
children.comment: Use this (or child) concept for analysis of transmembrane domains (buried and exposed faces), transmembrane helices, helix topology, orientation, inter-helical contacts, membrane dipping (re-entrant) loops and other secondary structure etc. Methods might use pattern discovery, hidden Markov models, sequence alignment, structural profiles, amino acid property analysis, comparison to known domains or some combination (hybrid methods).

children.definition: Analyse a network of protein interactions.
Analyse a known network of gene regulation.
Predict a network of gene regulation.
Predict a network of protein interactions.

Model a metabolic network.  This can include 1) reconstruction to break down a metabolic pathways into reactions, enzymes, and other relevant information, and compilation of this into a mathematical model and 2) simulations of metabolism based on the model.
children.comment: The terms and synyonyms here reflect that for practical intents and purposes, "pathway" and "network" can be treated the same.

children.definition: A data mining method typically used for studying biological networks based on pairwise correlations between variables.
Render (visualise) a network - typically a biological network of some sort.
Generate, process or analyse a biological network.
Identify or screen for 3D structural motifs in protein structure(s).
children.comment: This includes conserved substructures and conserved geometry, such as spatial arrangement of secondary structure or protein backbone. Methods might use structure alignment, structural templates, searches for similar electrostatic potential and molecular surface shape, surface-mapping of phylogenetic information etc.

children.definition: Decompose a structure into compact or globular fragments (protein peeling).
Identify structural domains in a protein structure from first principles (for example calculations on structural compactness).
Compare the architecture of two or more protein structures.
Identify the architecture of a protein structure.
children.comment: Includes methods that try to suggest the most likely biological unit for a given protein X-ray crystal structure based on crystal symmetry and scoring of putative protein-protein interfaces.

children.definition: Analyse the architecture (spatial arrangement of secondary structure) of protein structure(s).
Predict super-secondary structure of protein sequence(s).
children.comment: Super-secondary structures include leucine zippers, coiled coils, Helix-Turn-Helix etc.

children.definition: Predict and/or classify transmembrane proteins or transmembrane (helical) domains or regions in protein sequences.
Predict helical secondary structure of protein sequences.
Predict turn structure (for example beta hairpin turns) of protein sequences.
Predict open coils, non-regular secondary structure and intrinsically disordered / unstructured regions of protein sequences.
Predict secondary structure of protein sequences.
children.comment: Methods might use amino acid composition, local sequence information, multiple sequence alignments, physicochemical features, estimated energy content, statistical algorithms, hidden Markov models, support vector machines, kernel machines, neural networks etc.

children.definition: Compare protein secondary structures.
Analyse protein secondary structure data.

comment: This includes sequence-to-3D-profile alignment methods, which align molecular sequence(s) to structural (3D) profile(s) or template(s) (representing a structure or structure alignment) - methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
Use this concept for methods that evaluate sequence-structure compatibility by assessing residue interactions in 3D. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.definition: Align molecular sequence to structure in 3D space (threading).
Recognize (predict and identify) known protein structural domains or folds in protein sequence(s) which (typically) are not accompanied by any significant sequence similarity to know structures.
children.comment: Methods use some type of mapping between sequence and fold, for example secondary structure prediction and alignment, profile comparison, sequence properties, homologous sequence search, kernel machines etc. Domains and folds might be taken from SCOP or CATH.
Includes secondary structure assignment from circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopic data, and from protein coordinate data.
children.definition: Assign secondary structure from protein coordinate or experimental data.
Detect cysteine bridges (from coordinate data) in a protein structure.
Detect free cysteines in a protein structure.
children.comment: A free cysteine is neither involved in a cysteine bridge, nor functions as a ligand to a metal.

children.definition: Detect cysteines that are bound to metal in a protein structure.
Assign cysteine bonding state and disulfide bond partners in protein structures.
children.text: Protein cysteine and disulfide bond assignment

children.definition: Assign a protein tertiary structure (3D coordinates), or other aspects of protein structure, from raw experimental data.
Detect 'bumps' between residues in a structure, i.e. those with pairs of atoms whose Van der Waals' radii interpenetrate more than a defined distance.
Identify poorly packed residues in protein structures.
Validate protein geometry, for example bond lengths, bond angles, torsion angles, chiralities, planaraties etc.  An example is validation of a Ramachandran plot of a protein structure.
A method for making numerical assessments about the maximum percent of time that a conformer of a flexible macromolecule can exist and still be compatible with the experimental data.
Evaluate the quality or correctness a protein three-dimensional model.
comment: Model validation might involve checks for atomic packing, steric clashes (bumps), volume irregularities, agreement with electron density maps, number of amino acid residues, percentage of residues with missing or bad atoms, irregular Ramachandran Z-scores, irregular Chi-1 / Chi-2 normality scores, RMS-Z score on bonds and angles etc.

The PDB file format has had difficulties, inconsistencies and errors. Corrections can include identifying a meaningful sequence, removal of alternate atoms, correction of nomenclature problems, removal of incomplete residues and spurious waters, addition or removal of water, modelling of missing side chains, optimisation of cysteine bonds, regularisation of bond lengths, bond angles and planarities etc.

This includes methods that calculate poor quality residues. The scoring function to identify poor quality residues may consider residues with bad atoms or atoms with high B-factor, residues in the N- or C-terminal position, adjacent to an unstructured residue, non-canonical residues, glycine and proline (or adjacent to these such residues).

children.definition: Predict tertiary structure of protein sequence(s) without homologs of known structure.
Model protein backbone conformation.
comment: Methods might require a preliminary C(alpha) trace.
Scaffold selection, scaffold search, epitope grafting and design optimization are stages of backbone modelling done during rational vaccine design.

children.definition: Model, analyse or edit amino acid side chain conformation in protein structure, optimize side-chain packing, hydrogen bonding etc.
comment: Antibody optimisation is to optimize the antibody-interacting surface of the antigen (epitope).  Antigen optimisation is to optimize the antigen-interacting surface of the antibody (paratope). Antigen resurfacing is to resurface the antigen by varying the sequence of non-epitope regions.
Methods might use a residue rotamer library.

This includes rotamer likelihood prediction: the prediction of rotamer likelihoods for all 20 amino acid types at each position in a protein structure, where output typically includes, for each residue position, the likelihoods for the 20 amino acid types with estimated reliability of the 20 likelihoods.

children.definition: Model loop conformation in protein structures.
Build a three-dimensional protein model based on known (for example homologs) structures.
children.comment: The model might be of a whole, part or aspect of protein structure. Molecular modelling methods might use sequence-structure alignment, structural templates, molecular dynamics, energy minimisation etc.
This includes methods that predict the folding pathway(s) or non-native structural intermediates of a protein.
children.definition: Predict tertiary structure (backbone and side-chain conformation) of protein sequences.
Analyse, simulate or predict protein folding, typically by processing sequence and / or structural data.  For example, predict sites of nucleation or stabilisation key to protein folding.
Compare protein tertiary structures.
children.comment: Methods might identify structural neighbors, find structural similarities or define a structural core.

children.definition: Analyse protein structural data.
Predict RNA secondary structure (for example knots, pseudoknots, alternative structures etc).
children.comment: Methods might use RNA motifs, predicted intermolecular contacts, or RNA sequence-structure compatibility (inverse RNA folding).

children.definition: Analyse some aspect of RNA/DNA folding, typically by processing sequence and/or structural data.  For example, compute folding energies such as minimum folding energies for DNA or RNA sequences or energy landscape of RNA mutants.
Predict RNA tertiary structure.
Predict DNA tertiary structure.
Predict structure of DNA or RNA.
children.comment: Methods might identify thermodynamically stable or evolutionarily conserved structures.

children.definition: Predict RNA secondary structure (for example knots, pseudoknots, alternative structures etc).
children.comment: Methods might use RNA motifs, predicted intermolecular contacts, or RNA sequence-structure compatibility (inverse RNA folding).

children.definition: Align RNA secondary structures.
Compute the covariance model for (a family of) RNA secondary structures.
Process (read and / or write) RNA secondary structure data.

Analyse some aspect of RNA/DNA folding, typically by processing sequence and/or structural data.  For example, compute folding energies such as minimum folding energies for DNA or RNA sequences or energy landscape of RNA mutants.
Compare nucleic acid tertiary structures.
Compute Essential Dynamics (ED) on a simulation trajectory: an analysis of molecule dynamics using PCA (Principal Component Analysis) applied to the atomic positional fluctuations.
children.comment: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is a multivariate statistical analysis to obtain collective variables and reduce the dimensionality of the system.

children.definition: Analyse nucleic acid tertiary structural data.
Align (superimpose) exactly two molecular tertiary structures.
Align (superimpose) more than two molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment.

children.definition: Locally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity, common substructures etc.

children.definition: Globally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire structures.

Includes methods that align structural (3D) profiles or templates (representing structures or structure alignments) - including methods that perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.definition: Align (superimpose) molecular tertiary structures.
Align (superimpose) exactly two molecular tertiary structures.
Align (superimpose) more than two molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: This includes methods that use an existing alignment.

children.definition: Locally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity, common substructures etc.

children.definition: Globally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.
children.comment: Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire structures.

Includes methods that align structural (3D) profiles or templates (representing structures or structure alignments) - including methods that perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.
children.definition: Align (superimpose) molecular tertiary structures.
Search a database of molecular structure and retrieve structures that are similar to a query structure.
Compare protein tertiary structures.
children.comment: Methods might identify structural neighbors, find structural similarities or define a structural core.

children.definition: Compare nucleic acid tertiary structures.
Identify and remove redudancy from a set of small molecule structures.
Compare two or more molecular surfaces.
Compare two or more molecular tertiary structures.
Generate some type of structural (3D) profile or template from a structure or structure alignment.

A technique used to construct an atomic model of an unknown structure from diffraction data, based upon an atomic model of a known structure, either a related protein or the same protein from a different crystal form.
children.comment: The technique solves the phase problem, i.e. retrieve information concern phases of the structure.

children.definition: A method used to refine a structure by moving the whole molecule or parts of it as a rigid unit, rather than moving individual atoms.
children.comment: Rigid body refinement usually follows molecular replacement in the assignment of a structure from diffraction data.

children.definition: Refine (after evaluation) a model of a molecular structure (typically a protein structure) to reduce steric clashes, volume irregularities etc.
Calculate solvent accessible or buried surface areas in protein or other molecular structures.
children.comment: Solvent accessibility might be calculated for the backbone, sidechain and total (backbone plus sidechain).

children.definition: Calculate the molecular surface area in proteins and other macromolecules.
Calculate the positions of dots that are homogeneously distributed over the surface of a molecule.
children.comment: A dot has three coordinates (x,y,z) and (typically) a color.

children.definition: Compare two or more molecular surfaces.
Analyse the surface properties of proteins or other macromolecules, including surface accessible pockets, interior inaccessible cavities etc.

Virtual screening is used in drug discovery to identify potential drug compounds.  It involves searching libraries of small molecules in order to identify those molecules which are most likely to bind to a drug target (typically a protein receptor or enzyme).
children.comment: Virtual screening is widely used for lead identification, lead optimization, and scaffold hopping during drug design and discovery.

children.definition: Model protein-ligand (for example protein-peptide) binding using comparative modelling or other techniques.
comment: Methods aim to predict the position and orientation of a ligand bound to a protein receptor or enzyme.

Virtual screening is used in drug discovery to search libraries of small molecules in order to identify those molecules which are most likely to bind to a drug target (typically a protein receptor or enzyme).

children.definition: Model or simulate protein-protein binding using comparative modelling or other techniques.
Model the structure of a protein in complex with a small molecule or another macromolecule.
children.comment: This includes protein-protein interactions, protein-nucleic acid, protein-ligand binding etc. Methods might predict whether the molecules are likely to bind in vivo, their conformation when bound, the strength of the interaction, possible mutations to achieve bonding and so on.
